reviewText: First the DVD review: This DVD was/is put out by "Hens Tooth" video. (Hens Tooth?) Features the original theatrical trailer, which in itself is a gem; a wonderful stills gallery featuring behind the scenes making of the movie...priceless! And an awesome commentary by Tim Conway and the Director Lang Elliot who offer tons of little know facts and insight to this classic! This DVD is crisp and clear and so is the sound! The only thing this DVD lacks are the deleted and alternate scenes and alternate angles they showed on TV back in 1984. (see below for details) But, I'm happy to take what they give!I know this is going to sound odd, but this is my favorite comedy of all time! No question! I have always been a big fan of Tim Conway and Don Knotts! (Who isn't?) Both men are absolute geniuses and have been underused since this movie came out back in 1981. This movie left a huge impression on me when I was a kid! I have always wanted a house just like the one in this movie! Who wouldn't want a 252 room estate! You could almost sleep in a different room for a full year! I was equally impressed when I found out the house in this movie is a real house! It's the Biltmore House and gardens. The real house is in Asheville North Carolina. Although the Biltmore House doesn't have 252 rooms (darn!) it is an absolutely gorgeouse manor! I highly recommend you check out their website! They will even send you a free brochure which pulls out into a mini poster! I have one on my wall right now! Very cool!Anyways, back to the review...This is one movie that can be shared with the whole family! When this movie came out I was 10 years old and was so impressed by the look of it, the hysterical comedy, the cast, and the mystery storyline! You had to be there, but everytime and I mean EVERYTIME I saw this movie the theater was packed and sold out! Movies back then would run for 3-6 months at a time! (this is before even video and vcr's) I would clip every article or advertisement for this movie and I still have them today in a scrapbook! Yes, I am a fan!Tim and Don play two ameturish private detectives who are called in to investigate the murder of Lord and Lady Morley, the owners of the estate. Don plays the straight guy to a T! Tim plays a wacky, paranoidish, inventor/detective. One of Tims inventions is called a time gun, which goes off every hour! He is also afraid of a legendary creature called the "Wookalar"! A half pig half human creature that will "suck your brains right out your nose!" Very funny stuff! You have to see it for yourself! The two detectives run into a myriad of funny characters along the way in the Manors staff and housekeeprs/caretakers! Just when they think they know who the killer is..that suspect ends up dead! Hilarious!Now, here is something to note: I was extactic when this movie first aired on TV back in 1984 and happily taped it! Lucky for anyone else who taped it (and still has the tape like me!) because they showed scenes and alternate takes/angles that are NOT IN THIS DVD! They show a scene with Trisha Noble and Tim Conway eating dinner at a loooong dinner table that is just hilarious! Tim dresses up as Don's character, in hopes of "fooling" the killer, as a decoy. Trishas character just beats the crud out of Tim as she gets upset when people try to "trick" her! Hilarious!The next scene they showed was an extra scene of Tim trying to send off a Homing pigeon, with an update of their investigation to Scotland Yard. Tim has a whole crate of homing pigeons and every time he trys to send a message something happens to the bird! So, in the deleted scene Tim paints a pigeon black, so no one can see it at night thus nothing should happen to it, and when he throws it out the window of his room...the pigeon goes but the wings stay in his hands! Cruel? Yes, by todays standards, but still funny!Next, there is an alternate scene when the maid is preparing tea for Tim and Don and the killer slips poison in their cups. And there are a couple of alternate angle shots throughout the TV version.This is an absolute classic comedy! Buy it before it goes out of print!
summary: "A Sound? You mean like a Wookalar would make?" "Koowah!"

reviewText: That's one of Tim Conway's lines, which starts a bunch of gross notions that will make you giggle, big time. His silly sense of humor is all over this movie (he cowrote it).All I can say is, when you bring Tim Conway and Don Knotts together, you are sure to have fun.They are two of the funniest people ever.This was one of those flicks that, back in the 80's, came on tv on a Saturday afternoon and you'd watch it and laugh. My favorite running gags are the pigeons and the "alarm gun".This movie is right up my alley, along with stuff from Monty Python, Mel Brooks, Danny Kaye, Martin Short, Carol Burnett, Steve Martin, and also Woody Allen's early films.And the fact that it's a broad homage to whodunits is gravy. It's a great companion to Murder By Death, and Clue.
summary: "You know what my mother used to say to make you throw up?"

reviewText: Of the few films Tim Conway and the late great Don Knotts made together, this is by far their very best. The quality of the dvd looks and sounds great, although I'd still like to see this in a widescreen format.The jokes are still as funny today as they were when I first saw it as a kid, and Conway and Knotts are a superb comedy team. Parents with smaller children beware as there are a few scenes that might frighten them (the crypt, the torture chamber and the Wookilar). Otherwise this is good clean entertainment and no one will have to worry about being offended.

reviewText: This BDs low discounting is likely due to a relatively small fanbase.  Major studios would probably set SRP about $10-$15 lower, but Hens Tooth isn't that big and, as this is the first time the film has been preserved in its original widescreen aspect (or close to it), I suspect it may have been newly remastered for this release which would help justify the premium for a nearly bare-boned catalog title.  The film certainly looks better than I've ever seen it, but it still could use a lot of work in the restoration department.  I haven't listened to it yet, but it was exciting to see in the disc menu Tim Conway was involved in the audio commentary.  Sadly, that's about the only real extra on the disc.I would have also much preferred had Hens tooth better justified their high SRP by including a lossless audio track - something that's pretty much become a staple of the format.  Considering the film is only 91 minutes, they could have probably even fit in a stereo PCM track without compromising video compression, despite using a cheaper 25GB disc.  Compression looked fine even projected at 100 inches, though the video is very noisy, seemingly more from print degradation than natural grain; a little age compensation and clean up is clearly justified.I was also disappointed that the cut didn't include all of the scenes from my fond memory of the movie. Specifically:  the gag where Conway camouflages a pigeon by painting it black was omitted.  I saw the film theatrically, but was only nine at the time, so I can't recall if the missing scene was in the theatrical cut or something added for television, nor do I recall if it was included on the previous pan-and-scan dvd.  It felt like something else was missing, or even several somethings, but my memory is even more foggy on the matter.Ultimately, I'm grateful to have this Scooby-doo-like mystery in high definition (real HD, not the over-compressed lower res stuff that passes for HD in broadcast and streaming), but I hope someday Hens tooth can justify the expense of a more thorough effort.
summary: Over priced, under discounted, incomplete, but still worthwhile.

reviewText: The movie stars Tim Conway and Don Knotts two of the best comedians in Hollywood. Their antics make even the dourest among us laugh. These two are the zaniest copies of Sherlock Holmes and Doctor Watson I've ever seen. Tim Conway is the inventor and some of his inventions are more dangerous than helpful. They are sent to investigate the death of a rich man and his wife. The outcome is both a surprise and a delight. The setting for this hilarious tale is the largest privately owned house in the United States -- the Biltmore Mansion in Ashville, N.C.The juxtaposition of this elegant residence, crazy servants, sinister hidden passages, outlandish investigators, and a double murder make this a movie the entire family will enjoy. My son used to laugh so hard, tears would run down his face. If you like Abott and Costello and the Keystone Cops, you'll like The Private Eyes.

reviewText: A giant spooky house, a motley gang of servants, a femme fatale, and... a pair of detectives who probably couldn't locate their own backsides, even WITH a map. "The Private Eyes" is an entertaining  little comedy that gently glides along on the slapstick, fun running gags and the duo of Tim Conway and Don Knotts.Lord Morley and Lady Morley have been murdered, and Scotland Yard has sent in Dr. Tart (Tim Conway) and Inspector Winship (Don Knotts) to investigate. And after they almost get throttled by the butler for saying the word "murder," they begin investigating the strange assortment of servants -- the aforementioned homicidal butler, the uptight nanny, the sexy maid, the samurai cook who claims to only use his katanas for food, the crazy-eyed gypsy with his foot in a trap, and the incoherent hunchback.But then the servants start being murdered as well, and a poorly-rhymed poem left next to their corpses. And the bodies vanish before the duo can show the Morley heir, Phyllis (Trisha Noble), leaving Tart and Winship scrabbling to prove that a murderer is still loose in the mansion. But of course, nothing is quite as it seems...Despite the title, "Private Eyes" is not much of a detective story -- if you're like me, you'll have figured out the murderer's identity and the whole elaborate back-scheme in pretty short order. The fun is watching Tart and Winship bumble around the giant elaborate manor house, stumbling across dead bodies and murder machines.The center of it all is Knotts and Conway -- they are simply hysterical as the uptight, long-suffering Winship and the oblivious, often goofy Tart ("So he must have read about us in the newspaper and called us in to solve his murder!"). It's immensely fun to see these guys just bouncing around like ping-pong balls, and encountering one corpse after another.And though it sounds like they'd run out of fun twists about ten minutes into the movie, the running gags (the time-gun), dialogue ("You've got stuff all over your face." "He's oiling his brain") and the bizarre methods of killing people (Winship gets slooooowwwwllly pulled into a machine that waves around axes... while Tart tries to find something to cut the rope with) keep things amusing."The Private Eyes" aren't much good at gumshoeing (is that even a word?), but they are plenty of fun -- even as bodies pile up everywhere. "I'm out of the grave, and roaming the moores. If you want to be safe, you better lock all the windows and screens."

reviewText: If you like Tim Conway, Don Knotts, or Biltmore Estate, watch this movie. It's a pleasant, watchable movie. The music is appropriate. If you're a fan of classic monster/horror films, you'll notice some references to the genre. There were some very funny lines and hearty laugh out loud scenes; but, I expected more.As for Biltmore, it was a joy to see the house from an earlier time (1980). It was fun to figure out where in the House each scene was located and how the filmmakers used artistic license (such as secret passages when actually there are none). I enjoyed seeing the House with furniture in places where there would have been furniture just like someone was living there-in the hallways, beside the grand staircase.
summary: Biltmore, Conway, Knotts Fans-Watch This Movie

reviewText: Oh boy. What do I say?Hmm...If you're a fan - then no more need be said - enjoy.However, if you're unfamiliar with Tim Conway's writing style and the sniffling efforts of his pal Don Knotts - then this effort could be perceived as stumbling, inept, trite and singularly unfunny.And for fans of Knotts alone - like myself - there are so many more enjoyable options. Most of which everyone already knows by heart. My recommendation: Consider, 'No Deposit, No Return', which features a similar buddy-buddy dynamic, but with infinitely more enjoyable results.Movie Note:- Filmed at the famous Vanderbilt family estate in Asheville, North Carolina, The Biltmore is now a luxury hotel and tourist attraction run by one branch of the Vanderbilt family.It makes for quite the contrast to see it in this film - circa 1980 - and the incredible transformation which took place over the next few decades. When Conway & Knotts were there, it looked dilapidated and disused. To see it now, fully restored to its magnificent glory, wow.Check out their website (search The Biltmore via your favorite search engine) and compare it to the film.

reviewText: I watched this funny mystery movie when I was back in elementary school and then again when I was in middle school. It was hilarious and it managed to give me a surprise spook in between. This movie is a fantastical spoof of all the old Sherlock Holmes mysteries probably starring Basil Rathborne and Nigel Bruce (known as the most popular Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson). Don Knotts and Tim Conway take you on a happily spookily funny mystery through cemeteries and old haunted castles. This movie is worth a watch for all ages. I don't think of this movie as a classic in the usual sense, I think of it as a comedy that can measure up better than most modern day comedies.Don Knotts who in my mind is one of the great comedians of his day really takes lead of this movie and brings on some of the mightiest laughs I've ever had. Tim Conway is no slacker himself proving that he can carry the show all the way to the crashing, laughing end. You better not eat or drink during this movie, you'll surely choke or strangle to death. If you love this team up in The Private Eyes then I suggest checking out the movies The Apple Dumpling Gang 1 & 2, which is even more hilarious starring these pair.Check out The Private Eyes and witness some of the best comedy of your life!

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoy the work of Don Knotts and Tim Conway as solo entities but of course, they also made several pictures together and I think this Independent One (with Conway as co-writer)is the best.  Some will reserve that for "The Apple Dumpling Gang" but they were secondary in that first one (they were the leads in the sequel which bombed...) and in this one, everything resolves around these two bumbling detectives investigating a murder.Funny thing about this film is that the first time through, I found the pace too slow and the gags a bit corny but with repeated viewings, I began to focus even more closely on Knotts/ Conway and their chemistry together and found myself enjoying it more and more... The torture chamber and gas station scenes are particular standout scenes!As to the rest of the supporting cast who appear as the Kooky Mansion Staff where the main story takes place, veteran Brit Comic Actor Bernard Fox as the Butler is the best with some very funny moments (especially when he throws fits when he hears the word "Murder" and has to be brought under control...) Trisha Noble is fine as the female lead who ultimately is found to be the source of the killings (we think!) of her adopted rich parents to support her gambling habit.This is not only a funny film but a clean one from start to finish and thoroughly enjoyable if you exercise a little bit of patience with it!
summary: A Fun Film Outing That Grows On You!

reviewText: This is the best Don Knotts & Tim Conway movie ever made! I laugh everytime I watch it! The jokes are hilarious and outrageous! This movie never gets old! I recommend everyone to buy this movie on DVD no matter the price - you will not be disappointed! It is a murder mystery that will leave you on the edge of your seat! Everyone on the Morley staff are killed but Dr. Tart and Inspector Winship have a hard time gathering the evidence they need before all the bodies vanish! I watched this movie the other day and it  helped me to feel good and forget about the bad day I had! After you see this movie, I would also recommend that you visit The Biltmore Estate in Asheville, NC where the movie was filmed! You can take a Behind the Scenes tour at Biltmore and see the room that was used as Tim & Don's bedroom in the Morley Mansion! I was not allowed to take pictures so you will have to visit the house for yourself!
summary: I LAUGH EVERYTIME I WATCH IT!!!!!

reviewText: Tim Conway and Don Knots work well together, and this movie does prove that.  At times there are some direction problems, continuity problems, and even a couple of mic's in shots here and there.  It obviously was low budget, but its definately one for the family, with bodily gags and some adult humor.  Nothing extremely bad, and kids will find it funny.Some really memorable lines come out of this, but in the end, its mostly bumbling idiot humor typical of the apple dumbling gang.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: The Big G. Spot "The Big G. Spot"
reviewText: The Private Eyes is a classic fun movie from when I was a kid. Don Knots and Tim Conway are a Comedic Duel of Great Perporsions in this film, their comedy compliments each other perfectly I don't think you could have found a better pair for this show. I know I get a lot of shows from when I was a kid and when I watch them I say to myself wow I can't believe I liked that when I was a kid but with this one it was not like that. When I was done I was truly glad I had bought this film and can't wait to watch it again. A Total Classic and Fun Movie. AAA+++
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well...Look, it's not Citizen Kane.  Or Gone with the Wind.  What it is is as much as anyone wanting a Tim Conway/Don Knotts movie could want.  Roger Ebert theorized that, to an extent, movies had to be reviewed based on whether they accomplished their purpose.  The Private Eyes does that.If you're the kind of person that thinks Don Knotts and Tim Conway are funny (like me) you're the kind of person that this movie is targeted to, and you won't be disappointed.
summary: Is This Really A Four Star Movie?!

reviewText: A typical Don Knots & Tim Conway comedy with them as private investigators. It's a good movie, but not as funny as some of their others....

reviewText: From henstoothvideo, details on the blu-ray restoration and deleted scenes:The Blu-ray edition of THE PRIVATE EYES was transferred from an archived 35mm Interpositive (IP) at 1080p high definition. The entire film was re-timed, shot by shot and color corrected on a state-of-the-art Spirit 4 Data Cine film scanner at Prime Focus (formerly Post Logic Studios) in New York. It underwent a rigorous digital "clean-up" to remove hundreds of dust and speckling imperfections. Some scenes in the original film were dimly lit intentionally by the filmmakers to make it look like the dark secret passageways one would expect in an old dark house mystery. The Blu-ray transfer was correctly timed to maintain the artistic integrity of cinematographer Jacques Haitkin's vision for the film. The technology employed in this new transfer delivers a huge improvement in the visual clarity and definition over the previous VHS and DVD versions.Regarding the deleted scenes; a lot of time and money was spent trying to locate the deleted scenes but they could not be found. We found a 16mm negative that was marked "Network Version", then transferred it to video and found no additional scenes. It was exactly the same as the theatrical version. We regret that the deleted scenes may never be seen again but they were not stored with the original materials in the New World Pictures library nor did NBC-Universal have a taped copy of the picture.and comments from Wookalars side-by-side comparison with the full frame DVD:For some more good news: This is really widescreen. Other people on these boards, I'm sure, know more about this, but just to let you know what I've seen--I compared the full-screen DVD to the Blu-Ray. I thought they were just going to chop off the top and bottom of that to make it 1.78:1. However, that's not it. There is new information on the left and right sides! This was definitely shot in widescreen, then cropped to TV dimensions. The framing always looked so fine to me in full-screen, I just assumed it was like that originally. Again, I don't know the official stats, but this is what I saw comparing them side-by-side.
summary: Details on the Blu-ray transfer, deleted scenes and widescreen:

reviewText: Not the best of the Conway/Knotts collaborations but still a nice view for a slow weekend afternoon. I will add it to my other movies from this comic team-up, but it will not be considered a favorite.
